title-group.article-title: A study on the surface modification of a specialized porous silicon membrane

abstract.p: The surface modification of a porous silicon membrane is presented in this paper. The base porous silicon membrane is fabricated by anodization and has a range of pore sizes and porosities. In order to change its wettability, the surface of the porous silicon membrane is modified using silane-octadecyl-trichlorosilane. The average contact angle of the modified porous silicon membrane against water exceeds 126°. This modified membrane is incorporated to form part of the anode plate in a novel passive micro direct methanol fuel cell. Its use leads to a decrease in methanol crossover and an increase in the operating time.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a result of its large specific surface area, low reflectivity, adjustable pore size and porosity, porous silicon has found use in many applications, such as a carrier for catalysis reactions and a plate in water and gas testing instruments.1–6 Additionally, the anodization process used to form porous silicon, is cheap and is compatible with the standard microfabrication techniques used in the semiconductor industry.3,5

The nanometer-scale structure of electrochemically fabricated porous silicon has a high reactivity in an oxidative environment.6–9 There are numerous Si–H bonds on the surface and the walls of the pores in freshly etched porous silicon.7 After the oxidation process, the Si–H bonds are replaced by Si–O bonds, and thus –OH groups are formed naturally, making the surface of the porous silicon hydrophilic.8

In order to meet different needs in various fields, the wettability of an ideal material should be able to be changed using simple methods. Both chemical processing and physical methods have been studied in the literature. A simple method is surface adsorption, however, in this case the adsorbed layer tends to flake off.10 Another physical approach for hydrophobization is to enhance the surface roughness using tribological methods, however, in this case any existing porous structure can be destroyed.11 Considerable attention has been paid to the use of chemical approaches because they are easy to perform and have excellent properties, including stable physical and chemical properties and good covalent bonding with the substrate.12 The principle behind the chemical approach is to graft organic molecules onto the hydrophobic groups using covalent bonding. It has been reported that fluorinated organic thin films, which were determined by the –CF3 group, were a good candidate for surface modification due to their unique chemical stability and anti-adhesive properties.13 Dodecylamine, which readily reacts with carbonate groups to produce a hydrophobic surface, has also been successfully used to create surface modifications.11 The excellent stability properties of alkylsilane molecular films, which contain a hydrophobic alkyl group, have resulted in their widespread use in surface modification studies.14 In addition, it has been reported that silicane which has a long carbon chain and is hydrophobic, can create modified surfaces with excellent hydrophobicity properties.15,16 Thus, it appears that an alkylsilane with a carbon chain is an ideal system for surface modification of porous silicon. The combination of the rough structure of porous silicon which aids hydrophobization and the hydrophobic self-assembled organic films formed by alkylsilane means that it might be possible to form a surface of porous silicon that was super hydrophobic.

In this paper, silane-octadecyl-trichlorosilane (OTS) is used to realize the hydrophobization of porous silicon. The contact angle of water, pure methanol and methanol solution against a surface-modified porous silicon membrane are measured. The membrane is hydrophobic for water but wettable for methanol, and thus it is an appropriate material for use in a passive micro direct methanol fuel cell (µDMFC).

sec.title: The principle of surface modification
sec.p: The chemical formula of OTS is CH3 (CH2)17SiCl3, and the molecule contains a long chain alkyl group (–C18H37), which is hydrophobic, and a hydrophilic functional group (–SiCl3). The OTS modification is a silanization process following a three step reaction (Figure 1). In step 1, the Si–Cl bond hydrolyzes in water to form a Si–OH bond, in step 2, the hydrolyzed OTS molecule is absorbed onto the substrate, and in step 3 adjacent hydroxyl groups (–OH) undergo a condensation reaction and eliminate water. After the polymerization reactions, a self-assembled OTS film forms which is hydrophobic as a result of the –C18H37 functional group.

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p: Considering the prposed experimental program, the porous silicon membrane was fabricated on an anode plate of a µDMFC. The detailed process can be found in Zhu et al.5 The porous silicon membrane was formed by anodization (40% HF solution: pure ethanol = 2:1, volume ratio) under a current density of 120–240 mA/cm2, an inductive coupled plasma was applied to etch the cathode side of the plate and form pores in the membrane.

For surface modification, the plates were cleaned in H2SO4/H2O2 (3:1) solution at 120 °C for 30 min. Then the samples were rinsed in deionized water and dried in a flow of N2. After that the samples were modified to be hydrophobic using OTS/ toluene solution (OTS: toluene = 1:500, volume ratio), at a temperature of 18 °C for 30 min. Finally, the samples were rinsed in chloroform and then in acetone.5

sec.title: The porous silicon membrane
sec.p: The morphology of the porous silicon was analyzed using scanning electron microscope (SEM) images (Figure 2). The average diameter of pores ranges from 10 to 30 nm and the calculated porosity ranges from 35% to 60%, for an anodization current density value between 120 and 240 mA/cm2. This shows that a high current density creates large pores. In fact the pores almost perforate the porous silicon membrane.

caption.p: SEM micrographs showing a cross-sectional view of porous silicon membranes (a) the average diameter is 30 nm, porosity is about 60% (240 mA/cm2, 40% HF solution: ethanol = 2:1) and (b) the average diameter is 10 nm, porosity is about 35% (120 mA/cm2, 40% HF solution: ethanol = 2:1).

sec.title: The surface contact angle of the porous silicon membrane
sec.p: The contact angles of the samples were measured to determine whether or not the self-assembled OTS film is hydrophobic. The bigger of contact angle, the more hydrophobic is the material. Both the growth start side and the growth termination side of porous silicon were chosen to measure the surface contact angles, and the results show that there is no difference between the surface contact angles on these two sides.

The contact angle against H2O is 126.0°, indicating that the self-assembled OTS film formed on the porous silicon is hydrophobic (Figure 3(a)). As illustrated in Figures 3(b) and (c), the self-assembled OTS film is not only unwettable for H2O but also for methanol solutions. However, it is wettable for pure methanol since the contact angle against pure methanol is only 56.1° (Figure 3(d)). This indicates that the surface of the self-assembled OTS film formed on the porous silicon membrane allows methanol diffusion but prevents water diffusion.

caption.p: The contact angle of the surface-modified porous silicon samples against (a) H2O, (b) 1 M methanol solution, (c) 3 M methanol solution and (d) pure methanol.

sec.title: Analysis of hydrophobization on the inner wallsof the pores
sec.p: The thickness of the porous membrane is about 200 µm, thus the contact angle of the inner wall of a pore cannot be measured directly. The scattering energy spectrum of the porous silicon membrane was measured to investigate if a self-assembled OTS film was formed on the walls of the pores. The percentage of carbon in the porous silicon membrane is only 2.18% before hydrophobization (Figure 4(a)) whereas it is 8.96% after the hydrophobization (Figure 4(b)). Thus, the only explanation for the increasing percentage of carbon is that it is caused by the OTS film. In other words, there are self-assembled OTS films formed on the inner walls of the pores in the porous silicon membrane, indicating that the hydrophobization was successful.

caption.p: The scattering energy spectrum of the porous silicon membrane which gives the elemental percentages: (a) before and (b) after the hydrophobization process.

sec.p: The chemical nature of a pore wall in porous silicon depends on the chemical bond formed on the surface of the pore wall. It has been reported in the literature that several bonds, such as Si–O and Si=O bonds, exist on the surface of the pore walls in porous silicon after an oxidation process.12 These Si–O and Si=O bonds make the structure of the pore wall similar to the Si/SiO2 interface13 and thus the contact angles for both Si and SiO2 substrates were measured to analyze the wettability of the pore walls of the porous silicon. The Si and SiO2 samples were surface modified using the same conditions as for the porous silicon membrane.

As illustrated in Figure 5 the contact angles for the Si sample against H2O, 1 M methanol solution and 3 M methanol solution are all larger than 90°, indicating that the self-assembled OTS film formed on the silicon substrate has good hydrophobicity properties, however, the contact angle against pure methanol is only 44.8°. Figure 6 shows that the surface wettability of the SiO2 sample is similar to that of the Si sample. Thus, it can be inferred that the inner wall of the pore is also hydrophilic to methanol but hydrophobic to water. We can draw the conclusions that the OTS coating technique can be used to create a porous membrane and that this membrane could be used in a passive µDMFC.

sec.title: Passive µDMFC with hydrophobic porous silicon membrane
sec.p: Figure 7(a) is a schematic diagram of a passive µDMFC containing the porous silicon membrane. The anode plate consists of two chambers, which are seperated by the hydrophobic porous silicon membrane, that are filled with pure methanol and methanol solution, respectively. The pure methanol can diffuse into the chamber containing the methanol solution, due to the concentration gradient across the membrane. Furthermore, the diffusion rate is self-regulating and depends on the rate of methanol consumption by the µDMFC (Figure 7(b)).

caption.p: (a) A schematic diagram of the passive µDMFC containing a hydrophobic porous silicon membrane, (b) the principle of methanol delivery; pure methanol can diffuse to the methanol solution, however, water in the methanol solution cannot diffuse into the methanol chamber and (c) a photograph of the assembled µDMFC.

sec.p: A µDMFC containing a hydrophobic porous silicon membrane was assembled, as shown in Figure 7(c). The methanol solution or water was pumped into the right chamber, with a flowrate of 1 mL/min using an external pump, no leakage was observed in the left chamber. This indicates that the surface-modified membrane allows methanol diffusion but prevents water diffusion. Furthermore, the prototype has an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 0.7 V and a maximum power density of 12.5 mW/cm2 at room temperature.5 This shows that the operating time of this µDMFC is more than three times as that of one fed with 2 M methanol solution.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presented a surface-modified porous silicon membrane that contained pores with sizes between 10 and 30 nm and a porosity level between 35% and 60% depending on the fabrication conditions. The created porous silicon membrane was subsequently hydrophobized using OTS. The contact angle of H2O against the hydrophobized porous silicon membrane exceeded 126°. A prototype of a passive µDMFC containing the membrane was assembled and shown to have an OCV of 0.7 V and a maximum power density of 12.5 mW/cm2 at room temperature. The membrane could also find use in microfluidics systems and diffusion membrane applications.
